HL7 Standard.summary: This IG is fundamentally based on FHIR for representing and exchanging HAI reports. It leverages FHIR's Questionnaire and QuestionnaireResponse resources as its core mechanism. While it acknowledges CDA and provides mappings for interoperability, CDA is not central to its approach. v2 and v3 are not directly relevant. Cross-paradigm integration is present in the form of mapping to CDA, but it's not a dominant aspect.

Geographic Scope.summary: This Implementation Guide focuses on standardizing the electronic submission of Healthcare Associated Infection (HAI) reports to the National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN) of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in the United States. It leverages US Core profiles and defines NHSN-specific value sets, indicating a national scope within the United States.

Domain Focus.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide focuses on standardizing the electronic submission of Healthcare Associated Infection (HAI) reports to the National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN) of the CDC. It primarily leverages the Questionnaire and QuestionnaireResponse resources to model NHSN forms and their completed responses, with a strong emphasis on public health surveillance and quality improvement related to HAIs. While it touches upon administrative aspects like facility and patient identification, its core purpose is to facilitate accurate and timely HAI data reporting for public health purposes.

Implementation Approach.summary: This IG primarily focuses on defining FHIR Questionnaires and QuestionnaireResponses for submitting HAI reports to the CDC's NHSN. It heavily relies on Data Profiles to structure the reports and Terminology to ensure consistent coding. While REST APIs are implied for submission, they are not explicitly defined. Forms & UI are central to the approach, as Questionnaires represent the forms. Decision Support, Documents, Messaging, Services, and Subscriptions are not significantly utilized.

Implementers.summary: This IG focuses on standardizing the electronic submission of Healthcare Associated Infection (HAI) reports to the CDC's National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN) using FHIR. Therefore, EHR systems are central to its implementation, as they will be the primary source of HAI data and responsible for generating and submitting the FHIR QuestionnaireResponse resources. Public Health Systems, specifically the NHSN, will be the primary recipient of the data, making them a core system type. Clinical Decision Support systems may play a role in identifying potential HAIs, and Research Platforms might utilize the aggregated data. Other systems have limited or no involvement.

Users & Stakeholders.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide primarily focuses on enabling healthcare systems to electronically submit Healthcare Associated Infection (HAI) reports to the CDC's National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN). The design is driven by the need for standardized, interoperable data exchange between healthcare facilities and public health agencies for surveillance and quality improvement. While clinical care teams provide the source data, the IG's design is primarily influenced by the requirements of public health agencies and the developers implementing the data exchange. Patients have minimal direct involvement.
